page.title: 11St. Mary's Church, Shipley.
page.content: It was built 1125-1175 by Knights Templars, of French stone brought up the river Adur, on the site of a Saxon Church mentioned in the Domesday Book. The unusual "sacrificial" shaped Iron Age stone in the porch indicates Pagan Worship.Features include double splay Norman windows and fine stained glass by Kemp. The most recent window, 1984, commemorates 50 years of the Shipley Scouts. The Shipley Reliquary, of 13th Century Limoges enamel, stolen in 1976 is replaced by a replica. The oldest of the bells was cast in the church yard. There is a memorial to Sir Charles Merrick Burrell, Bart.,M.P. for Shoreham for 52 years and an alabaster tomb to the Caryll family dated 1616. A Sarsen stone marks the Composer J. Ireland's grave. The Queen attended a wedding at the church in 1952 shortly before her Coronation.
